explanation: MAX_CLIENTS: needed to determine whether the second clause of the for (i < MAX_CLIENTS) uses only the loop counter and a non‑modifiable object. We must know if MAX_CLIENTS is a compile‑time constant (macro/enum/const) or a modifiable variable (which would violate the rule if modified in the loop body). CLIENT_SOCKS: we need the declaration (is it a global array, macro, accessor, or function-like entity?), element type and storage/qualifiers (volatile/atomic). If CLIENT_SOCKS is not a plain array (e.g. a macro or accessor with side effects) or its access has side effects or aliases the loop counter, the for‑loop second/third clause constraints could be violated. Also knowing whether writes to CLIENT_SOCKS[i] modify any object referenced in the second clause is required. MHD_INVALID_SOCKET: required to know its definition/type/value and whether assigning it to CLIENT_SOCKS[i] has any side effects (e.g. if it is a function‑like macro) or could implicitly modify other objects referenced by the loop control. struct WsData (definition): to confirm the type and semantics of ws->sock (its type, whether it can alias the loop counter or be involved in side effects). Although ws is local, ensuring ws->sock access has no hidden side effects (macros, overloaded semantics) is necessary to conclude the loop counter is the only object modified by the loop body and that the second clause does not use objects modified inside the body.
